interesting topic I get asked what is research computing all the time people say oh you're the
HPC guy or are you do big data or no you must be the machine learning person and
what I would say is research computing is all of those things and more research computing is actually a collection of
tools collection of very powerful tools and it's important that we have flexible
tools at our fingertips to fit into the way that we work because one tool is not
enough as researchers we are working in workflows we typically have a number of
steps that we follow and if we're dealing with data I've kind of shown a canonical workflow at the top here which
is pretty representative of what a lot of data scientists or researchers or in different domains do every day and so
typically we are collecting data at some point this might be from traditional data sources like databases perhaps
we're doing earth observation work and we're maybe collecting data directly from satellites or down links from
satellites perhaps we have Internet of Things sensors in the field that we're
collecting data from and so on you get the idea but then we're also generating events we're either generating the
events in reaction to data streams that are coming through perhaps we're putting data into s3 and events are being
generated that way maybe we're using our software development kits to generate events based on changes that are
happening in in data streams or we're capturing real-time feeds of information through a service like Amazon Kinesis
and then we have the concept of workflows where we're running analysis and there are two main models we see the
first is batch batch workflows are typically not time-sensitive this is where it's okay for you to wait several
hours or maybe several days for a results we have customers that do very calm
analysis in the cloud and they can sometimes wake wait several weeks for a results so the point is that what they
do what they typically do is land data into s3 as a storage service they then
spin up tools like HPC clusters like Hadoop clusters using add abuse batch
potentially to do some kind of analysis that is time-consuming that is batch driven and then they write
the results back out to s3 so that's one model that we see another model that we see commonly is real-time workflow
so this is where time to a result is much more important perhaps we're asking questions of data that we need results
in seconds too or perhaps we're doing real-time analysis of streaming data perhaps we're looking at window analysis
those kinds of things and so here I've represented common tools that are used by our research community like SPARC
Apache spark that's trivial to run on a mrl elastic MapReduce service which is a
managed to dupe platform on the cloud okay it's a checkbox when you want to create a spark cluster to be able to do
that kind of work or maybe we're using lambda a service platform to react to
events and process data as they come through in a stream and so on but then ultimately what we're doing with those
results all those answers or those secondary data products is we want to share them and we want to collaborate
and we also want to be able to make those results available so other people can validate them and so we may use
tools like Jupiter notebooks or maybe we're using Zeppelin on top of Hadoop to start doing some kind of interactive
analysis of our results you get the idea now where does HPC fit into this where
does machine-learning fit into this it is a tool in a workflow and it's important that you choose the right
tools that are flexible enough to be able to be strung together to suit your evolving workflows as a research
community and that's one thing we spent a lot of time thinking about carefully at AWS so let's talk a little bit about
clusters clusters in the cloud are an ephemeral tool now what do I mean by
that well it's very common for data to come in from from sources that we've talked about a little bit already and
land that into s3 because s3 is durable it's very scalable and
it's actually very cost-effective so it's very common to use that as the sync for your data and then we can generate
an event and spin up a cluster on demand so we can actually in a completely automated way spin up a fully fledged
HPC cluster to do high throughput computing or high-performance computing on that is just hours no one else is
sharing it and we can have that for as long as we need to we can pulled we can
connect to that over RDP or remote desktop or VNC or SSH usual methods we
can connect to a login node and then we can pull data into the shared storage environment of that cluster we can do our processing in a batch driven fashion
perhaps on that cluster we can write the results back out to s3 and then what do
we do with the cluster we can get rid of it we don't need it the cloud presents a
model where you only need to to spin up the resources that you need and you only need them for the time to do that to the
investigation and when you couple that with an on demand model for how you pay for these resources you start thinking
about these tools is just being ephemeral steps in a workflow it's very different to an on-premise environment
where you have a shared infrastructure that lots of different people are using and you're trying to perhaps get in a
queue or trying to change the job specification to run on the cluster faster or only use a part of the cluster
and you're invariably fitting your job to fit the infrastructure here we're able to get infrastructure quickly and
automate that and the infrastructure gets out of the way so we can do our research now the clouds also pretty
interesting because it gives us a huge ecosystem of tools and compute environments and compute types so it's
very flexible in that sense and here I've shown what we typically call our instance families we have general
purpose computer we have compute optimized storage optimized you get the picture we even have more modern
instances that give you accelerate options give you GPU for general-purpose GPU compute using CUDA or OpenCL and we
also have more recently an instance type that gives you FPGAs on the server and
so we're seeing our researchers in some cases move towards these accelerator options to speed up their processing
and so what this means in the cloud on AWS is that you can build fit for purpose clusters so if I'm going to do
deep learning work and I know that I can accelerate the training of my deep learning models with GPUs then I can
spin up a cluster based on GPUs for the period of time that I'm doing my training maybe that's a few hours maybe
that's a few days maybe that's a few weeks but then when I'm done I shut it down well maybe I know that my
